awd_titl_txt: Fundamentals of co-crystallization of polyoxacyclobutane and water
awd_abstract_narration:
Crystals composed of two distinct molecules organized within a lattice (co-crystals) are variously known as clathrates, host-guest compounds, intermetallic compounds amongst metals, or hydrates if water is included.  A well-known example of an organic co-crystal is the gas hydrate formed from the co-crystallization of methane and water.  The co-crystallization of polymers, very long chain organic molecules, with small molecules is unusual, and those with water are especially rare. The focus of this research project is to study a rare class of co-crystals based on the polymer, polyoxacyclobutane (POCB), and water.  The researchers will investigate the types of phases that POCB hydrate can form as well as the rates of formation. Understanding the unique behavior of POCB hydrate is important, because it could be applied to a thermal desalination process that involves no membranes.  The project will involve training graduate and undergraduate students in state-of-the-art research, as well as some curriculum development related to the topic of the project.  The researchers will also perform outreach activities to pre-college students around the topic of molecular shapes and intermolecular interactions, especially in the context of gas hydrates and their relevance to energy. 

POCB can co-crystallize with water to form a hydrate, which melts upon heating above 37 degrees Celsius.  Melting yields either a homogeneous liquid phase, or a water-rich and a polymer-rich two-phase mixture. The properties of the POCB hydrate are unique: (1) the melting point of the co-crystal exceeds that of the two pure species; (2) co-crystallization can occur either from a liquid-liquid equilibrium (LLE) state or from a homogeneous liquid solution; (3) the hydrate is highly insensitive to salt; and (4) the hydrate melting point fortuitously happens to be almost exactly at human body temperature. This combination of properties makes POCB unique not just amongst polymers, but amongst all materials. Very little is known about the POCB hydrate. Even the most basic information, such as the melting point of the hydrate in the high molecular weight limit or its heat of fusion, is missing. This research project will explore the thermodynamics and crystallization kinetics of POCB hydrate and examine the coupling between LLE and crystallization in which the polymer co-crystallizes with the solvent. The unique phase behavior of POCB could be used for a purely-thermal desalination process that requires no vacuum or pressure, no refrigeration, and no membrane. Such a process may enable waste-heat-based desalination and the desalination of high salinity waters. This research project will provide the first proof-of-principle and a preliminary technoeconomic evaluation of such a process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many polymers are semicrystalline, i.e. they have regions that form precisely-ordered crystalline unit cells. The polymer polyoxacyclobutane (POCB) is a rare example of a polymer that can form a crystalline hydrate, i.e. when combined with water, it forms crystalline unit cells that include the repeat units of both the polymer as well as water. Remarkably, the polymer is intrinsically hydrophobic and demixes from water under molten conditions. Thus, its affinity for water appears only in the solid hydrate state. Further, the hydrate melts at a temperature higher than of the pure POCB and pure water. This combination of hydrate formation in the solid state, phase separation in the liquid state, and the unexpectedly-high melting temperature gives POCB-water mixtures a phase diagram that is unique in the polymer world. This project examined thermodynamics of phase behavior and kinetics of hydrate crystallization in POCB-water mixtures.

Intellectual merit: Even basic questions about hydrate crystallization were unknown at the start of this project, e.g. how does composition of the crystallizing mixture affect hydrate crystallization kinetics, does isothermal crystallization occur at fixed rate (as is known for homopolymers), and does the temperature-dependence of crystallization kinetics resemble that of homopolymers? Indeed, while the focus of this project was on POCB-hydrate, most of these questions have not been addressed for any other polymer-solvent pair capable of cocrystallization. This project shows that hydrate crystallization from the homogeneous liquid state process resembles homopolymer crystallization qualitatively, although there are some conceptual differences. In contrast, hydrate crystallization from two-phase liquid conditions is altogether different, and mixing intensity can play a significant role. Salt is shown to greatly reduce polymer-water miscibility under molten conditions and somewhat reduce the hydrate melting temperature. At least some of these results may be applicable to other polymer-solvent mixtures that are capable of cocrystallization.

Broader impact: This project lays the foundation for developing new materials based on hydrate forming polymers that may be humidity- or temperature-sensitive, or whose self-assembly can be tuned by water. Several graduate and undergraduate students were trained during this project. The results of the research were published in three peer-reviewed papers, with one more submitted, and one more in preparation. The project fostered collaboration between the two principal investigators and led to development of new techniques that may be useful more broadly in studies of polymer crystallization. The principal investigators conducted outreach at local high schools to attract students towards careers in science and engineering.


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: Sachin S Velankar

    Sachin Velankar and Sudesna Banerjee
